title: Haley Hanson and Caroline Flynn’s Impact on the 2015 Season in the Big Ten
text:
The Nebraska soccer program has been a consistent force since its first season in 1995. Over several years, players have gone on to be professional and highly respected athletes.
Two well-known standouts developed within the program are Haley Hanson and Caroline Flynn. Hanson left her mark on the university with several accolades, including being named a Big Ten Co-Offensive Player of the Week, on the Big Ten Preseason Honors List and a participant in the U.S. U-23 Women’s National Team Training Camp. She is currently playing professionally in the NWSL with the Orlando Pride, earning a championship with the team last year in 2024.
Caroline Flynn, distinguished herself during her college years. In 2013, Caroline won the Big Ten regular season and tournament alongside her teammates. During her first season in 2012, she started 18 out of 20 games and upon graduation, Caroline’s accomplishments extended to being drafted as the 40th overall pick in the NWSL.
Are Caroline and Haley among the best soccer players to emerge from the Nebraska soccer program? Let’s look at data that compares Big Ten players and teams to the Nebraska athletes.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(waffle)
library(gt)

soccer <- read_csv("ncaa_womens_soccer_playerstats_2015.csv") |> 
  filter(Player != "Totals") |> mutate(PlayerTeam = paste0(Player, ", ", Team))

big10 <- soccer |> 
  filter(Team
    %in% c("Nebraska Huskers", 
          "Illinois Fighting Illini", 
         "Indiana Hoosiers", 
         "Iowa Hawkeyes", 
          "Maryland Terrapins, Terps",
          "Michigan St. Spartans", 
          "Minnesota Golden Gophers", 
          "Northwestern Wildcats", 
          "Ohio St. Buckeyes",
          "Penn St. Nittany Lions",
          "Purdue Boilermakers", 
          "Rutgers Scarlet Knights", 
          "Wisconsin Badgers"),
    Goals >= 3
  )

carohaley <- big10 |> 
  filter(Player
  %in% c("Caroline Flynn",
         "Haley Hanson"
         ))

ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data=big10, aes (x=reorder(PlayerTeam, Goals), weight=Goals), fill="lightgrey") + 
  geom_bar(data=carohaley, aes (x=reorder(PlayerTeam,Goals), weight=Goals),  fill="red") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Goals Scored", 
    title="Flynn and Hanson's Impact on the Big Ten", 
    subtitle="Two elite Husker soccer players who went on to play professionally, show their goals underrate them.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | Alana Textor"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
theme(
    plot.title.position = "plot",
   plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
   plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
   axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
)









Several notable players played in the Big Ten alongside Flynn and Hanson during the 2015 season, including U.S. Women’s National Team member Rose Lavelle and Costa Rica National Team player Rocky Rodriguez.
Hanson scored three goals in the 2015 season, significantly less than her other seasons at Nebraska. However, Hanson was injured during the season and was able to score more goals than most. Flynn scored five goals tied with seven other players in the Big Ten and led the Huskers in goals.


Code
started <- read_csv("ncaa_womens_soccer_playerstats_2015.csv") |> 
  filter(Player != "Totals") |> mutate(PlayerTeam = paste(Player, Team)) |> mutate(GS = as.numeric(GS))

gamesstarted <- started |> 
  filter(Team
    %in% c("Nebraska Huskers", 
          "Illinois Fighting Illini", 
         "Indiana Hoosiers", 
         "Iowa Hawkeyes", 
          "Maryland Terrapins, Terps",
          "Michigan St. Spartans", 
          "Minnesota Golden Gophers", 
          "Northwestern Wildcats", 
          "Ohio St. Buckeyes",
          "Penn St. Nittany Lions",
          "Purdue Boilermakers", 
          "Rutgers Scarlet Knights", 
          "Wisconsin Badgers")
  )

carohaleyy <- gamesstarted |> 
  filter(Player
  %in% c("Caroline Flynn",
         "Haley Hanson"
         ))

Flynn <- c("Goals"=5, "ShAtt"=35)
Hanson <- c("Goals"=3, "ShAtt"=22, 15)
BigTenAvg <- c("Goals"=3, "ShAtt"=15, 22)

iron(
 waffle(
   Flynn, 
        rows = 2, 
        xlab="Flynn", 
        colors = c("black", "red")) +
          labs(
            title="Husker Soccer vs. Everyone Else", 
            subtitle="Flynn, Hanson and the Big Ten Average of Goals and Shot Attempts.") + 
   theme(    
     plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
),
 waffle(Hanson, 
        rows = 2, 
        xlab="Hanson", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "white")
        ),
  waffle(BigTenAvg, 
        rows = 2, 
       xlab="Big Ten Average\n1 square = 1 goal or shot attempt", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "white")) +
  
   labs(caption="Source: NCAA | Graphic by Alana Textor")
) 









Flynn’s goal and shot attempts were far higher than other players in the Big Ten. Flynn attempted 35 shots and scored five goals, averaging one goal for every seven shots taken.
Hanson scored three goals aligning with the Big Ten average and recorded 22 shot attempts. Hanson scored one goal for almost every seven shots taken.


Code
table <- read_csv("ncaa_womens_soccer_playerstats_2015.csv")

big10table <- soccer |> 
  filter(Team
    %in% c("Nebraska Huskers", 
          "Illinois Fighting Illini", 
         "Indiana Hoosiers", 
         "Iowa Hawkeyes", 
          "Maryland Terrapins, Terps",
          "Michigan St. Spartans", 
          "Minnesota Golden Gophers", 
          "Northwestern Wildcats", 
          "Ohio St. Buckeyes",
          "Penn St. Nittany Lions",
          "Purdue Boilermakers", 
          "Rutgers Scarlet Knights", 
          "Wisconsin Badgers")
  )

big10table |> 
  filter(Team == "Nebraska Huskers") |> 
  replace_na(list(Goals = 0, Assists=0)) |>  
  mutate(GoalsAssistsPerGame = round((Goals+Assists)/as.numeric(GP), 2)) |> 
  select(Player, GoalsAssistsPerGame) |> 
  arrange(desc(GoalsAssistsPerGame)) |> 
  filter(GoalsAssistsPerGame > 0) |>
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    GoalsAssistsPerGame = "Goals + Assists Per Game"
  ) |>
   tab_header(
    title = "How Many Goals and Assists Per Game for the Huskers?",
    subtitle = "Junior Caroline Flynn averaged .29 goals and assists per game, where sophomore Haley Hanson averaged .20 goals and assists per game."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Alana Textor |  **Source:** NCAA: Women's Soccer Player Stats 2015")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Haley Hanson" | Player == "Caroline Flynn"
      )  
  )








How Many Goals and Assists Per Game for the Huskers?


Junior Caroline Flynn averaged .29 goals and assists per game, where sophomore Haley Hanson averaged .20 goals and assists per game.


Player
Goals + Assists Per Game




Jaylyn Odermann
0.47


Jaycie Johnson
0.44


Sydney Miramontez
0.35

0.20

0.18


Courtney Claassen
0.18

0.13

0.12


Michaela Loebel

By: Alana Textor | Source: NCAA: Women’s Soccer Player Stats 2015








The list of Nebraska players are listed alongside the average number of goals and assists per game. Caroline Flynn is listed right underneath notable players, like retired professionals Jaycie Johnson (Ackerman) and Sydney Miramontez. Caroline Flynn averaged .29 goals and assists per game, followed by Haley Hanson with around .20 goals and assists per game.
Caroline and Haley were strong competitors and leaders in college athletics, but to list them as some of the best players in the Big Ten is open to interpretation. Caroline retired shortly after her professional debut for Kansas City FC in 2017. This season, Haley’s team, the Orlando Pride, fell short in the NWSL Championship semi-finals.

title: The Growth of the NWSL
text:
The National Women’s Soccer League (NWSL) is one of the fastest-growing leagues internationally. What began in 2012 with eight teams, has grown to 14, with plans to add two more teams in the cities of Boston and Denver.
The ultimate goal for every team in the league is to win the Championship. This is a major accomplishment and an achievement worth celebrating. In 2024 and 2025, two different teams earned the honor and what a better way to analyze the winning teams than with this data?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(patchwork)
library(ggalt)

nwsltwentyfour <- read_csv("2024 NWSL Stats - Sheet1.csv") |> mutate(season = 2024)
nwsltwentyfive <- read_csv("2025 NWSL Stats - Sheet1.csv") |> mutate(season = 2025)
nwsl <- bind_rows (nwsltwentyfour, nwsltwentyfive)

Pride <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Orlando Pride")
Washington <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Spirit")
Gotham <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Gotham FC")
KC <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Current")
NC <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Courage")
Portland <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Thorns")
Bay <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Bay FC")
Chicago <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Red Stars")
Racing <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Louisville")
SD <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Wave")
UR <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Royals")
LA <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Angel City")
OL <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Reign")
Houston <- nwsl |> filter(Squad == "Dash")


labellist <- c("Angel City", "Wave", "Louisville", "Royals")

labels <- nwsl |> filter(Squad %in% labellist)

ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=nwsl, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="lightblue") +
  geom_point(data=nwsl, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="lightblue") +
  geom_line(data=Pride, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#633492") +
  geom_point(data=Pride, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#633492") +
  geom_line(data=Washington, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="gold") +
  geom_point(data=Washington, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="gold") +
  geom_line(data=Gotham, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#9ADBE8") +
  geom_point(data=Gotham, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#9ADBE8") +
  geom_line(data=KC, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#008080") +
  geom_point(data=KC, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#008080") +
  geom_line(data=NC, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#AB1D37") +
  geom_point(data=NC, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#AB1D37") +
  geom_line(data=Portland, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#971E1F") +
  geom_point(data=Portland, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#971E1F") +
  geom_line(data=Bay, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#0C2032") +
  geom_point(data=Bay, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#0C2032") +
  geom_line(data=Chicago, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="lightgreen") +
  geom_point(data=Chicago, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="lightgreen") +
  geom_line(data=Racing, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="purple") +
  geom_point(data=Racing, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="purple") +
  geom_line(data=SD, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="lightpink") +
  geom_point(data=SD, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="lightpink") +
  geom_line(data=UR, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="yellow") +
  geom_point(data=UR, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="yellow") +
  geom_line(data=LA, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="hotpink") +
  geom_point(data=LA, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="hotpink") +
  geom_line(data=OL, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="royalblue") +
  geom_point(data=OL, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="royalblue") +
  geom_line(data=Houston, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#FF6900") +
  geom_point(data=Houston, aes(x=season, y=Attendance, group=Squad), color="#FF6900") +
    geom_text(data=labels |> filter(season == max(season)), aes(x=season + .15, y=Attendance, group=Squad, label=Squad)) + 
    scale_x_continuous(breaks=c(2024, 2025), limits=c(2023.5,2025.5)) + 
  labs(
    x="Season", 
    y="Attendance", 
    title="Attendance plays a significant role in the NWSL", 
    subtitle="NWSL teams share a significant difference in fan presence between the 2024 and 2025 season.", 
    caption="Source: NWSL | By: Alana Textor"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The league’s viewership reached an all-time high in the 2025 season, with an 18 percent in contrast to the 2024 season. However, although women’s sports are on the rise, the attendance for some NWSL teams have decreased over the past year.
Teams such as Angel City and the San Diego Wave, both based in California, experienced a significant drop in attendance. This could be due to several factors such as the traffic, the retirement of notable players such as Alex Morgan at the end of the 2024 season, etc.
Other teams with a decrease in attendance include the Utah Royals and Racing Louisville. The factors behind the decline are endless, as the Royals underwent a coaching change within the past year and Racing Louisville, is still working to find its footing, with 2025 marking its fourth season in the league.
Despite these challenges, the teams continue to defy the statistics against them while having large and supported fan bases.


Code
nwslfirst <- read_csv("2024 NWSL Stats - Sheet1.csv") |> mutate(season = 2024)
nwslsecond <- read_csv("2025 NWSL Stats - Sheet1.csv") |> mutate(season = 2025)
nwsll <- bind_rows (nwslfirst, nwslsecond)


pride <- nwslfirst |> 
  filter(
    Squad == "Pride"
  )


pridebar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nwslfirst, aes(x=reorder(Squad, Pts), weight=Pts)) +
  geom_bar(data=pride, aes(x=reorder(Squad, Pts), weight=Pts), fill="#633492") +
  coord_flip() +
 labs(
    x="", 
    y="Number of Points in the 2024 Season"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()



gotham <- nwslsecond |> 
  filter(
    Squad == "Gotham FC"
  )



gothambar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nwslsecond, aes(x=reorder(Squad, Pts), weight=Pts)) +
  geom_bar(data=gotham, aes(x=reorder(Squad, Pts), weight=Pts), fill="#9ADBE8") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Number of Points in the 2025 Season"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()

pridebar + gothambar + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "The Difference in NWSL Champions",
    subtitle = "Orlando Pride was projected to win the 2024 Championship which they did, however \nnobody could have predicted the eighth seed Gotham to win in 2025.",
    caption = "Source: NWSL | By: Alana Textor"
  )  & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









There is a clear contrast between the 2024 and 2025 NWSL Champions.
In 2024, many predicted that the Orlando Pride would win the Championship. They finished their regular season in first place with 60 points and featured several standout players, including Marta and Barbra Banda.
In 2025, Gotham FC, the underdogs, won the championship for the second time in three years. Gotham finished the regular season with 36 points, seven places behind the first seed and the expected favorite to win, the KC Current, with 65 points.


Code
nwsltopscorer <- nwsl |> 
  separate(`Top Team Scorer`, into=c("Top Team Scorer", "Goals"), sep="-") |> 
  mutate(
    `Top Team Scorer` = str_trim(`Top Team Scorer`), 
    Goals = as.numeric(Goals),
    PlayerTeamSeason = paste0(`Top Team Scorer`, ", ", Squad, " ", season)
    )

tophighlights <- nwsltopscorer |> filter(Squad == "Pride" | Squad == "Gotham FC")


ggplot() + 
  geom_lollipop(
    data=nwsltopscorer, 
    aes(y=reorder(PlayerTeamSeason, Goals), x=Goals),
    horizontal = TRUE,
    size = 1,
    color = "black",
    alpha=.3) + 
  geom_point(
    data=nwsltopscorer, 
    aes(x=Goals, y=PlayerTeamSeason), 
    color="black") + 
  geom_lollipop(
    data=tophighlights, 
    aes(y=reorder(PlayerTeamSeason, Goals), x=Goals, color=Squad),
    horizontal = TRUE,
    size = 1) + 
  geom_point(
    data=tophighlights, 
    aes(x=Goals, y=PlayerTeamSeason, color=Squad)) + 
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#9ADBE8", "#633492")) + 
  labs(
    x="Goals", 
    y="", 
    title="Orlando Pride and Gotham FC's lead goal scorers", 
    subtitle="Esther Gonzalez and Barbra Banda led their teams in goals for their back-to-back seasons.", 
    caption="Source: NWSL | By: Alana Textor"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The top goal scorers for Gotham FC and the Orlando Pride in the 2024 and 2025 seasons remained the same two players. For Gotham, Spanish national team striker Esther Gonzalez recorded nine goals in 2024 and increased her total to 13 in the 2025 season. Orlando’s Zambian national team striker Barbra Banda led the team with 13 goals in 2024 and eight goals in 2025. Both of these strikers are highly valuable to their clubs, with Gonzalez receiving a contract extension and Banda signing a four-year deal
The NWSL will continue to be on the rise and add highly-valuable players and investors to its league. Women’s sports has evolved over the past five years, allowing more growth within the league and its teams.
